data.title: Han / Zeta Ophiuchi Star Facts (Type, Distance, Magnitude, Age, Colour, Location and more)
data.meta_description: Han (Zeta Ophiuchi) is a blue main sequence star in the constellation of Ophiuchus. It can be seen in the night sky.
data.text:
Han is a naked-eye star, so you don't need a telescope or binoculars when you look up on a clear night. The lower the magnitude, the easier it will be to see it.

The Michigan Spectral Classification for Han is O9.5 Vn. The Hipparcos or Simbad spectral class is O9.5V, and it is the latter which will be used for descriptions on this site.

Radial Velocity and Proper Motion

In simplistic terms, all non-rogue stars, like planets, orbit around a central object, although that is actually not true. Where is the centre of the Solar System. For simplicity it's the central star, such as the Sun. In the case of a star, it's the galactic centre. The constellations we see today will be different than they were 50,000 years ago or 50,000 years from now.

Proper motion details the movements of these stars and is measured in milliarcseconds. Han is moving 24.79 ± 0.15 milliarcseconds/year towards the north and 15.26 ± 0.2 milliarcseconds/year east if we saw them in the horizon.

The radial velocity, the speed at which the Han is towards the Sun, is -9.00000 km/s with an error of about 5.50 km/s . When the value is negative, the star and the Sun are getting closer to one another; likewise, a positive number means that two stars are moving away. It's nothing to fear as the stars are so far apart they won't collide in our lifetime, if ever.
